If the CandidatesProcessor.seedRedirectsNewSeeds setting is 'true' (the 
default), then when a seed URI results in a redirection, the target URI 
will be considered a new seed, and announced to the crawler components 
that care about knowing the seed set. (For example, any scoping rules 
that derive their behavior from the seed set, or the seeds report.)

The TextSeedModule will also notice this announcement, and if the 
textSource bean implements the WriteTarget interface, try to write the 
new seed to that target (and if it fails, log/alert a non-fatal 
warning). The example configuration uses a ConfigFile pointing to 
'seeds.txt', and ConfigFile is a valid WriteTarget.

So you could set seedRedirectsNewSeeds to 'false', and the redirects 
wouldn't be considered seeds at all. There'd be no attempt to write them 
to the file. But also, they or their outlinks might not be in-scope as 
desired.

If you wanted to keep promoting the redirects to be considered seeds, 
but not change the seed file, you could make the seeds.txt file 
non-writable by the user that launched the crawler process. This would 
generate "problem writing" warnings for each redirected-new-seed that 
couldn't be written.

You could also specify the seeds textSource as a ConfigString, inline in 
your configuration file (or alternatively via a Spring XML <include> 
element referring to another suitable XML file). Since ConfigString 
doesn't implement WriteTarget, again no attempt to append the new seeds 
would occur... but again there'd be a warning ("nowhere to log added 
seed").

You'd have to modify the source of TextSeedModule, or add your own 
ReadSource implementation (that implements a no-op WriteTarget) for use 
as the textSource property, if you wanted to suppress the warnings 
entirely.

- Gordon
